This is why I introduced the Taking Account of Bureaucrats Spending (TABS) Act, which would, for the first time, empower the American taxpayers to hold the Bureau accountable by restoring the power of the purse and subject the CFPB to the congressional appropriations process.

Paul Clement, who was appointed by the Supreme Court to defend the CFPB in this case, admitted in response to a question during the hearing that the Dodd Frank provision exempting CFPB from the congressional appropriations process makes the Bureau ‚Äúless responsive‚Äù to Congress.
This is especially troubling since the Bureau receives most of its funding through an opaque and arbitrary formula from the Federal Reserve System, and not from Congress.

The Bureau ‚Äúwields enormous power over American businesses, American consumers, and the overall U.S. economy.‚Äù PHH Corp. v. CFPB, 881 F.3d 75, 165 (D.C. Cir. 2018)(en banc)(Kavanaugh, J., dissenting).

However, I also have the humility to acknowledge that Congress lacks the power to divest the President of his Commander-in-Chief authorities under Article II.
As a Member of Congress, I believe I have a special duty to jealously guard legislative prerogatives, including the power to declare war, and to provide a check on Executive Branch overreach.
This was in recognition of the slow pace and inefficiency of legislative proceedings under the Articles of Confederation.
Don‚Äôt forget the Framers of the Constitution specifically rejected a proposal that Congress be empowered to ‚Äúmake war‚Äù and implied power for the President to ‚Äúrepel sudden attacks.‚Äù
Of course, that is precisely the scenario here involving the President‚Äôs decisive defensive strike against Soleimani in response to the attack on our Embassy.

Finally, according to the OLC, ‚Äúif our Armed Forces otherwise lawfully stationed in a foreign country were fired upon and defended themselves, we doubt that such engagement in hostilities would be covered by the consultation and reporting provisions of the War Powers Resolution.‚Äù
Furthermore, the War Powers Resolution applies only to the deployment of ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù bodies of military personnel, and would not apply to a drone strike.

And the War Powers Resolution, 50 U.S.C. 1541-48, does not limit the the President‚Äôs power to act without Congress.  At most, it merely imposes a reporting & consultation requirement on the President until Congress passes a concurrent resolution to terminate the military action.
The courts have generally declined to review the exercise of such unilateral Executive power.

‚Ä¶and his duty to take care that the laws be faithfully executed generally empower him to deploy the Armed Forces abroad without a declaration of war by Congress or other congressional authorization.
Specifically, the OLC has said that the President‚Äôs inherent, constitutional authority as Commander-in-Chief, his broad foreign policy powers‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶if the President determines that the action would be anticipatory self-defense or otherwise serves the interests of the United States ‚Äî at least where the nature, scope and duration of the anticipated hostilities are limited.

In recent years, the Justice Department‚Äôs Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) has opined that the Constitution authorizes the President, as Commander-in-Chief, to order military action without congressional permission‚Ä¶
But dating back to the Prize Cases in 1863, the Supreme Court has long held that the President may act without Congress to defend the nation.
It is true that the Constitution gives Congress the sole power to declare war and the sole power of the purse to either fund or defund military action.

To my colleagues complaining about the absence of explicit congressional authorization for the Soleimani strike, a helpful reminder: Article II, Section 2 of the Constitution provides: ‚ÄúThe President shall be Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States.‚Äù
